data.title: Ingvald Martin Undset (1853-1893)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Ingvald Undset born 1853 Trondheim, Sør-Trøndelag, Norway died 1893 Oslo, Norway including parents + descendants + 1 photos + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Descendants

Profile last modified 4 May 2019 | Created 3 May 2019

This page has been accessed 614 times.

Biography

Ingvald Undset was an archeologist and the father of the novelist and Nobel Prize winner Sigrid Unset.

He was born 9 November 1853 in Trondheim, the son of Hallvard Halvardsen Undset and Øllegård Kristine Dahl. Ingvald spent his formative years in Trondheim, where he attended the Latin School. He graduated in 1871 and the following year went to Oslo to study.[1]

Ingvald was listed in the 1865 Norway Census, living in Trondheim with his family. Living in the household were his parents, Halvor Undseth and Kristine Øllegaard Undseth (born Dahl); and his siblings: Halma Christence, age 6; and Kristine Halvora, age 2. [2]

On 29 July 1881, Ingvald was married to Marie Nicoline Charlotte Gyth at Kalundborg, Denmark.[3] They were the parents of three daughters, Sigrid, Ragnhild, and Signe.

He was employed as an assistant at the University's Old Testament Collection from 1875 until his death. He earned a doctorate in archeology in 1881, and his dissertation, which was published in German, made him famous in his field of work and study. Ingvald and his family lived at Rome for a time, and then moved to Kalundborg in Denmark before returning to Oslo in 1884.[4]

By the early 1890s, Ingvald's health declined. At the time of the 1891 Norway Census, he was living in Oslo at 89 Keysers Gade, along with his wife, Anna Marie Nicoline Charlotte Undset, and their children: Sigrid, Ragnhild and Signe. No occupation was listed for him. [5] He died in Oslo 3 December 1893 at the age of 40. His remains were buried at the church at Trefoldighet 11 December 1883.[6]
